articles.author: Shalma Wegsman
articles.description:
A new proposal makes the case that paraparticles — a new category of quantum particle — could be created in exotic materials.             
The post ‘Paraparticles’ Would Be a Third Kingdom of Quantum Particle first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: ‘Paraparticles’ Would Be a Third Kingdom of Quantum Particle

articles.author: Joseph Howlett
articles.description:
The mathematician Tai-Danae Bradley is using category theory to try to understand both human and AI-generated language.            
The post Where Does Meaning Live in a Sentence? Math Might Tell Us. first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Where Does Meaning Live in a Sentence? Math Might Tell Us.

articles.author: Yasemin Saplakoglu
articles.description:
Complex neural pathways likely arose independently in birds and mammals, suggesting that vertebrates evolved intelligence multiple times.            
The post Intelligence Evolved at Least Twice in Vertebrate Animals first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Intelligence Evolved at Least Twice in Vertebrate Animals

articles.author: Ben Brubaker
articles.description:
When pigeons outnumber pigeonholes, some birds must double up. This obvious statement — and its inverse — have deep connections to many areas of math and computer science.             
The post How a Problem About Pigeons Powers Complexity Theory first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How a Problem About Pigeons Powers Complexity Theory

articles.author: Janna Levin and Steven Strogatz
articles.description:
Despite the hype, it’s been surprisingly challenging to find quantum algorithms that outperform classical ones. In this episode, Ewin Tang discusses her pioneering work in “dequantizing” quantum algorithms — and what it means for the future of quantum computing.            
The post What Is the True Promise of Quantum Computing? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: What Is the True Promise of Quantum Computing?

articles.author: Pie de Página
articles.description: A short text by Camilo Ocampo, published on Pie de Página and translated by Scott Campbell, that looks at recent developments at the National Autonomous University of Mexico. Since the publishing of this article, the struggle has spread throughout UNAM, with reports of five departments on “total strike” as of Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Those... Read Full Article
articles.title: UNAM seeks to demobilize students, but protests continue

articles.author: The Dugout
articles.description: The Dugout presents a look at the revolutionary life and legacy of Martin Sostre. Support The Dugout on Patreon here and listen to the show here. Martin Sostre was more than a political prisoner—he was a revolutionary thinker who reshaped the prison abolition movement from behind bars. In this episode of The Dugout, we uncover the life... articles.title: Martin Sostre: A Legacy of Jailhouse Law, Prefigurative Politics and Revolt

articles.author: The Beautiful Idea
articles.description: On September 6th of last year, 26 year old University of Washington graduate Ayşenur Ezgi Eygi was shot and killed by IDF soldiers while doing accompaniment in the West Bank of Palestine with International Solidarity Movement (ISM). In this episode, we speak with a friend of Ayşenur’s who had travelled to the West Bank to... Read Full Article

articles.author: Black Rose Anarchist Federation
articles.description: An analysis of the recent wave of repression against international students and how communities might respond. The Trump administration has begun disappearing international students and workers from university campuses. This article, written by three academic workers, argues that this escalation was made possible by a campaign of repression initiated by universities themselves. After analyzing where... articles.description: In this column, we present our monthly roundup of political prisoner, prison rebel, and repression news, happenings, announcements, action and analysis. Packed in as always are updates, fundraisers, and birthdays. There’s a lot happening, so let’s dive right in! Protests Erupt Following DHS Abduction of Mahmoud Khalil and Crackdown on Palestine Solidarity "The group…dismissed the... Read Full Article

If you’ve spent any time among people who want to better our world, you’ve probably heard a lot of talk about “organizing.” In the United States, activists use this term to describe any number of activities intended to oppose oppression, from planning... articles.description: Protests against billionaire Elon Musk and his growing attacks on federal workers, veterans, and social programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid, continued to gain momentum on Saturday, as thousands took part in hundreds of #TeslaTakedown demonstrations across the US and beyond, despite an attempt by small groups of neo-Nazis, Proud Boys, and Trump supporters... A dozen people gathered in Bloomington, IN on March 22 for a “Dogs Not DOGE” protest at the only Tesla charging station in town. Upon arrival, cops were just dispersing after harassing an unhoused woman sitting nearby the charging station. For an hour,... Read Full Article

It’s important to understand the root causes of this turn towards right-wing populism, to... Read Full Article

articles.description: Analysis from the Lake Effect Collective on the recent attack on Mahmoud Khalil at Columbia University. Mahmoud Khalil, a participant in Columbia’s path-breaking Palestine solidarity encampment, has been abducted from his home, labeled a “national security threat,” detained and shipped to Louisiana pending deportation. This abduction and its justification distill four years of state responses... Read Full Article

There, at a location supposedly searched by the state government in September 2024, they found three cremation ovens, clandestine graves, hundreds of human remains, and countless personal...
